comments: n/a
N/A

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a bit of differential equations. I had taken differential equations in high school and felt that my prior experience with this material was much clearer than the instruction in this course. Often, I felt like the way the course was taught made the material unnecessarily complicated and confusing.
Basic overview of ordinary differential equations and how to solve them.
Theory of ordinary differential equations  how to recognize and solve all kinds of ODEs with different methods.
How to brute force solve many different kinds of differential equations - this is the kind of content you can teach yourself by reading a Wikipedia page once. It's not riveting.
None

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
I think the time set aside in lecture to do practice problems with other members of the class is a real strength. I think those moments are a good way to identify which parts of the lectures were a bit tougher to apply into real problems.

I think being virtual made this course very tough. I felt like the course content could have been communicated in a much clearer manner.

I don't think this course worked super well in a virtual setting. I had a very hard time following the lectures usually, and I think that having a set of lecture slides so that they were organized and the students could get the relevant information more easily could be helpful.
New professor, fewer tedious problem sets, and a more generous approach to assessments are all needed.

Strengths:
- Gave a comprehensive overview of ODEs and how to solve them
Weaknesses:
- Lectures were disorganized and hard to follow
- Most teaching in the course amounted to listing out methods of solving with lots of hand-waving and not a lot of proofs or even intuition
- Feedback on exams and homework was often late, limited, or missing entirely

Strengths: Very few. Grading is rather lenient, though.
Weaknesses: Ariel was not very helpful at all, and he didn't record several lectures which made it difficult to keep up in different time zones. Moreover, he wasn't very responsive to emails.

This course is not very well taught. The course covers various method for solving different differential equations, but the topics are not presented in a very interesting or compelling fashion, and the material becomes extremely forgettable. Lectures often felt pointless, like I could have just read about the material in a tenth of the time it took him to explain it in class and walked away with a better understanding. The professor just lists off different methods for solving ODEs, and then you practice those methods on different ODEs he assigns you. The way I see it, if this is all a professor does, then there is no point in having a professor at all. Problem sets were sometimes way too long and often we were left to teach ourselves the material.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Having breakout room problem sessions during every lecture was great, it really allowed us to practice each concept and make sure we actually understood it before leaving class and also broke up zoom lectures.
Zoom? Bad. Online lecture? Bad. No feedback or interaction with professor? Also bad.

Succeeded:
- I was able to hear the professor lecture
Did not succeed:
- Trying to collaborate on math problems in a virtual lecture sucks
He should record lectures!! Or make lecture notes more thorough!

It is impossible to read the professor's handwriting when he is writing on his ipad. His ipad often had connection issues as well. Exams over zoom seemed to work well, though it was always a scramble to scan them at the end. Thankfully the professor was understanding when it came to these delays.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. The topic is interesting and Professor Jaffe really cares about having his students understand the content. ODEs  are actually pretty fun to solve. The lectures can sometimes be a little confusing because Professor Jaffe's notes can be messy but he is always willing to answer questions and review concepts after class/in his office hours. You definitely need to be proactive in the class, in terms of asking for information, practice exams, or answer keys otherwise you will not get them. However, the topic is great for those who enjoy problem solving and not proofs and want to learn more about ODEs.
I would not recommend this course to another student unless it is required for their major. I just think there are better courses to learn differential equations.
Only if you are very interested in physics and/or calculus.

Absolutely not. This is an incredibly boring and uninvolved area of math. Sure, differential equations are useful but it's not like you can't just look up how to solve one when you come across it.  If you have the opportunity to take literally any other math course instead, you should. Take this course only if you absolutely must.

Let's face it  basically anybody taking this course is doing so because it's required for their major. If you need to take it, then take it; otherwise, if you really love ODEs, just go learn them from Paul's math notes.
Not really, unless you have to take it. Maybe consider the ENAS version.

Probably not. Would have much rather taught myself the material than sitting through Jaffe's painfully dull lectures. Unfortunately, most students who take this course need it for a requirement. Like bad-tasting medicine, you will probably just have to take it and deal with it.
